results.headline: F.B.I. Agents Solve the Terrorist Problem
results.summary_short: “The Kingdom” takes aim at the ethical nuances and ideological contradictions of the war on terror and blasts away.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Kingdom

results.headline: Quarterback With a Parenting Knack
results.summary_short: “The Game Plan” is so likable that it glides over its many plot holes.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Game Plan

results.headline: The Malleable Nature of Sexuality
results.summary_short: A campus comedy with a dirty mouth and a surprisingly wise mind, “Freshman Orientation” uses identity politics as a road to romance and emotional maturity.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Freshman Orientation

results.headline: What Kind of Fool Is Love? No Matter, the Search Is On
results.summary_short: Playing a canny old papa bear dispensing nuggets of advice to a flock of unruly cubs in “Feast of Love,” Morgan Freeman has a role he could act in his sleep.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Feast of Love

results.headline: Brothers, and Their Baggage, in India
results.summary_short: Wes Anderson’s main characters share with him a passion for collecting rare objects and unusual experiences, all of which they handle with exquisite, jealous care.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Darjeeling Limited

results.headline: When Jim Crow Came to Town, With Eviction Notices
results.summary_short: There are ghosts haunting “Banished,” about the forced expulsion of black Southerners from their homes in the troubled and violent decades after the Civil War.
results.display_title: Banished: How Whites Drove Blacks Out of Town in America

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Banished: How Whites Drove Blacks Out of Town in America

results.headline: Las Vegas Under Siege by Zombies and a Mutant
results.summary_short: The third installment in the video-game-derived series of films is not exactly dull but never interesting either.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Resident Evil: Extinction

results.headline: Following His Trail to Danger and Joy
results.summary_short: There is plenty of sorrow to be found in “Into the Wild.” But though the film’s structure may be tragic, its spirit is anything but.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Into the Wild

results.headline: Rap Away the Tears
results.summary_short: A bold Brazilian melodrama that moves to the rhythm of the streets, “Antonia” traces a year in the lives of four young women who form a rap group and fend off tragedy.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Antonia

results.headline: A Bashful Young Fairy Tale
results.summary_short: There’s nothing sophisticated about the comedy in “Sydney White,” a peppy, ultra-P.C. variation on “Snow White.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sydney White

results.headline: Reflections of Don Quixote
results.summary_short: Elmore Leonard once said that the key to telling an exciting story was leaving out the parts that people skip.  “Quxiotic/Honor de Cavalleria” is composed of little else.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Quixotic/Honor de Cavalleria

results.headline: Old-Style Male Bonding Turns Toward the Tender
results.summary_short: In “The Man of My Life,” the French director Zabou Breitman and her screenwriting partner Agnès de Sacy examine male bonding from a feminine perspective.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Man of My Life

results.headline: Topless Girls! (And Other Things Far Too Wildly Hilarious to Mention)
results.summary_short: The main audience for “Good Luck Chuck” wants to confront one of the central cultural questions of our time: Will Jessica Alba take her top off?

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Good Luck Chuck

results.headline: Bibliophiles With Pride and Prejudice, Some in Need of Gentle Persuasion
results.summary_short: “The Jane Austen Book Club” is such a well-acted, literate adaptation of the 2004 best seller that your impulse is to forgive it for being the formulaic chick flick that it is.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Jane Austen Book Club

results.headline: Good, Bad or Ugly: A Legend Shrouded in Gunsmoke Remains Hazy
results.summary_short: “The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford” adds another gauzy chapter to the overtaxed James myth, if not much rhyme or reason, heart or soul.
results.display_title: The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford

results.headline: Urban Woe
results.summary_short: Filled with moody shots of Zabar’s and lonely city streets, “Adrift in Manhattan” looks dreamy and feels even less substantial.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Adrift in Manhattan

results.headline: That Red on White Is Blood on Snow
results.summary_short: Something wicked this way comes in the nifty horror film “The Last Winter,” crawling through the hallways and howling into the dread night.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Last Winter

results.headline: Using Art to Exorcise His Demons
results.summary_short: There is no shortage of documentaries about mentally ill artists, but “My Name Is Alan and I Paint Pictures” finds a fresh way into the subject.
results.display_title: My Name Is Alan and I Paint Pictures

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of My Name Is Alan and I Paint Pictures

results.headline: A China of Ripeness and Rigidity
results.summary_short: A delicate figurine of a movie, “Beauty Remains” is an account of a tragic love triangle set in China in 1948, just before the Communists won the civil war.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Beauty Remains

results.headline: Who Needs Plot When You’ve Got Dragons?
results.summary_short: “Dragon Wars: D-War”  is such a breathless, delirious stew, it’s impossible not to be entertained, provided — this is crucial — you have a sense of humor.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dragon Wars
